Tiberius Caesar Augustus reigned as the second Roman Emperor from 14 BCE until 37 BCE. While Tiberius was an accomplished military leader and administrator, his rule was ultimately associated with brutality and terror, leaving the Roman Empire with a troubled history.

See the fact file below for more information about Tiberius Caesar Augustus, or you can download our 28-page Tiberius Caesar Augustus worksheet pack to utilize within the classroom or home environment.

Key Facts & Information

EARLY LIFE

Tiberius Caesar Augustus, born Tiberius Claudius Nero, was the second Roman Emperor who reigned from BCE 14 to 37.

His parents, Tiberius Claudius Nero and Livia Drusilla, gave birth to him on November 16, 42 BCE.

Tiberius’ father was a member of a famous Roman family, while his mother was a Roman noblewoman descended from the Claudians, a highly regarded aristocratic clan.

Born in 38 BCE, Nero Claudius Drusus also known as Drusus the Elder, was his brother who served in the Roman military and held high-ranking administrative positions.

However, in 39 BCE, their mother, Livia, divorced their biological father and married Octavian, later known as Emperor Augustus.

Augustus raised Tiberius in his household, providing him with military and administrative training suitable for a Roman noble.

Augustus noticed Tiberius’ potential and eventually trained him for leadership.

Augustus dispatched him to various military operations, where he demonstrated his effectiveness as a commander and garnered numerous military awards.

His preparation for leadership included participation in diplomatic missions and government posts in several provinces.

Tiberius established that he was both a skilled military leader and a good student, both of which proved important as Emperor.

When Tiberius’s father died in 32 BCE, he was nine years old.

At a young age, he had already delivered a eulogy at the rostra.

In 29 BCE, he joined his stepfather in a triumphal chariot ride to commemorate Antony and Cleopatra’s defeat at Actium.

MARRIAGE

Tiberius Caesar Augustus’ challenging marriage history had a significant impact on his political career. Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa, Augustus’ commander and personal friend, allowed the marriage of his daughter Vipsania Agrippina to Tiberius.

Reports suggest that Tiberius harbored a deep affection for his first wife, Vipsania, with whom he fathered a son named Drusus Julius Caesar.

However, in order to preserve the imperial succession, Augustus ordered Tiberius to marry Julia the Elder, Augustus’ own daughter, who had recently become widowed.

He divorced Vipsania in 11 BCE.

Tiberius and Julia’s opposing personalities, along with the emotional distress resulting from the arranged marriage, made this marriage unhappy for both parties.

The fact that they were childless when they married increased Tiberius’ growing dissatisfaction with his position in the Julian family and the imperial court.

SUCCESSION AND REIGN

He started his career in the military and excelled in many missions.

Tiberius led successful battles in Gaul and Germania, expanding the Roman Empire’s borders and bringing calm to the dangerous frontier provinces.

His military prowess earned him the respect of both the legions and the Roman Senate.

Notably, during his co-consulship with Augustus in 12 BCE, he strengthened his political position among Rome’s aristocracy.

Despite his military skill and status as Augustus’ apparent heir apparent, Tiberius was dissatisfied with his role in the imperial succession and Roman political maneuvering.

Around 6 BCE, he abruptly decided to retire to Rhodes, where he spent several years.

Tiberius’ retirement was defined by his self-imposed exile from political and military activity, during which he spent time studying and contemplating.

Although the reasons for his retirement remain unclear, it was assumed that it was due to his troubled relationship with Augustus and discontent with imperial politics, especially after his forced divorce from Vipsania and marriage to Julia.

Tiberius’ retirement lasted until 2 BCE, when Augustus called him back to Rome, most likely due to the deaths of his planned heirs, Gaius and Lucius Caesar, which created a vacancy in the succession.

When Tiberius returned, he resumed his responsibilities and continued to serve in high-ranking positions, eventually succeeding Augustus as Emperor in 14 BCE.

His time at Rhodes, however, remained a distinct and somewhat perplexing chapter in his life, demonstrating the complex interaction between his own wants and the demands of his dynastic position.

Emperor Augustus, Tiberius Caesar’s stepfather, orchestrated a sophisticated and strategically planned procedure to ascend to the Roman throne.

Initially, Augustus preferred his direct descendants to succeed him, namely his grandsons through Julia the Elder, Gaius, and Lucius Caesar.

However, their early deaths, combined with the death of Tiberius’ own brother, Drusus the Elder, left Augustus with minimal options.

As a result, Augustus accepted Tiberius as his son and successor, but not until Tiberius had to take on his nephew Germanicus, the popular son of his brother Drusus, as his own heir.

Tiberius’ succession was also dependent on his famed military prowess, which he had demonstrated in numerous campaigns, strengthening his eligibility as a ruler in the eyes of Rome’s elite and armed forces.

Both the Senate and Tiberius himself, known for his reluctance to embrace the title of Emperor and its obligations, welcomed Tiberius’ ascent to the throne in 14 BCE with a mix of acceptance and hesitation.

During his early reign, he pursued Augustus’ policies, cementing the Roman Empire’s dominance and expanding its borders through military conquests, particularly in Pannonia, Germania, and Raetia.

He also proceeded to expand the Roman administrative infrastructure, which included legal and financial changes.

He is known for budgetary conservatism, which helped to preserve a strong state treasury, as well as judicial reforms, which included limiting the power of specific authorities in order to reduce corruption and abuse of power.

The aftermath of the devastating Battle of the Teutoburg Forest in 9 BCE, in which Germanic tribes led by Arminius defeated three Roman legions under Publius Quinctilius Varus, was one of the most difficult military circumstances Tiberius faced.

Tiberius was instrumental in restoring order on the German frontier following this catastrophic loss.

Tiberius was able to maintain the frontier by restoring discipline and morale in the soldiers and redefining Rome’s defensive boundaries to avoid similar assaults by Germanic tribes.

Intricate senatorial politics and an increasingly strained relationship with the Roman Senate and nobility marked Tiberius’ political reign.

He was known for his cold and quiet attitude, preferring to work via surrogates like his Praetorian prefect, Sejanus, who wielded considerable power in Rome.

This reliance on Sejanus eventually backfired, as he gained authority and began to function as a de facto ruler, even indulging in conspiratorial operations.

Tiberius eventually recognized Sejanus’ threats and organized his downfall and execution in 31 BCE, which sparked a series of purges of reputed Sejanus allies, creating an environment of mistrust and terror throughout Rome’s upper ranks.

Tiberius grew increasingly reclusive after Sejanus’ death, retiring to his house on Capri, from where he reigned until his death in 37 BCE.

Tiberius’ final years of leadership were marked by growing reclusiveness as he withdrew to the island of Capri.

He then monitored and oversaw state affairs from afar, sparking suspicions of decadence and paranoia.

Meanwhile, additional treason trials and deaths worsened the political situation, leaving Rome in the hands of administrators.

While Tiberius’ legacy is a mix of admiration for his administrative ability and condemnation for his later autocratic leadership, his reign was unquestionably crucial to the building of a solid imperial government in the early Roman Empire.

His reign laid the groundwork for future emperors, but it also contributed to the harsher ideas of imperial power that defined the Julio-Claudian dynasty.

Throughout history, Tiberius’ era remains difficult, with researchers constantly reassessing his accomplishments and flaws.

CHALLENGES OF TIBERIUS CAESAR AUGUSTUS

As emperor, Tiberius Caesar Augustus faced numerous problems, including political intrigues, administrative changes, military concerns, and personal issues, all of which put his leadership to the test.

Tiberius, despite being Augustus’ stepson, was not the first option for succession, resulting in tension and a need to show legitimacy.

His path to succession was complicated, and he frequently appeared hesitant to take on the position of Emperor.

Tiberius had to deal with the Roman Senate and other political personalities, each with their own agenda.

His relationship with the Senate was difficult; they were accustomed to Augustus’ charismatic authority, and Tiberius’ more quiet style drew fewer followers.

Tiberius trusted his Praetorian prefect, Sejanus, who had tremendous political power in Rome.

However, Sejanus’ ambition and subsequent collapse fostered an environment of fear and mistrust, resulting in countless charges and purges of accused traitors among the Roman elite.

Tiberius implemented administrative reforms to uphold Augustus’ objectives and ensure the empire’s stability.

Despite being economically prudent, his frugality may not have won over those who benefited from a more liberal approach to imperial expenditures.

Tiberius had military challenges, including maintaining Rome’s frontiers and dealing with rebellions in provinces such as Illyricum.

He also had to deal with the aftermath of the Teutoburg Forest tragedy, which dealt a major blow to Roman military prestige and strategy.

Tiberius’ quiet and enigmatic personality hindered his ability to develop a dominant public image.

This resulted in a lack of popularity among the general public, who frequently admired emperors with greater charisma and prominence.

Tiberius withdrew to Capri during his rule, delegating administration to talented but ambitious lieutenants.

This retreat fueled bad rumors about his actions and oversight of the government.

Tiberius struggled to select a suitable heir after his death.

DEATH

It is widely assumed that Tiberius died on March 16, 37 BCE, following an almost 23-year reign as Emperor.

As Tiberius grew older, the subject of succession became increasingly important. His own son, Drusus, had died under suspicious circumstances, so attention went to his grandnephew Caligula and his potential as Rome’s next emperor.

Tiberius spent his final years in self-imposed solitude on the island of Capri, where he controlled the empire’s affairs from a distance.

His health was declining, and some ancient historians reported that his behavior had grown increasingly unpredictable and delusional.

The Praetorian Prefects and other Roman authorities successfully administered the empire during this time.

Tiberius summoned his future successor, Caligula, his great-nephew and adopted grandson, to his side as his health deteriorated.

After Tiberius died, the Praetorian Guard hastily declared Caligula Emperor.

The Senate and troops quickly embraced the new emperor, while Tiberius’ death elicited mixed feelings because of his eventual image as an autocratic and remote ruler.

The specific circumstances of Tiberius’ death remain unknown.

However, Tiberius’ death signaled the end of the Julio-Claudian dynasty’s second rule, paving the way for Caligula’s brief and turbulent reign.

Frequently Asked Questions

Who was Tiberius Caesar Augustus?

Tiberius Caesar Augustus, born Tiberius Claudius Nero, was the second Roman Emperor, succeeding Augustus Caesar. He ruled from 14 AD to 37 AD. Tiberius was known for his complex personality, marked by periods of competent governance and also bouts of tyranny and paranoia.

What were some significant events during Tiberius’ reign?

Tiberius faced several challenges during his reign, including the aftermath of Augustus’ death and consolidating his power. Notable events include the suppression of revolts in Germania and Pannonia, the trial of his political enemies (such as Sejanus), and his retreat to Capri in later years, where his rule became increasingly reclusive and autocratic.

How was Tiberius perceived by his contemporaries?

Tiberius’ rule was marked by mixed perceptions. While some saw him as a capable administrator who maintained stability in the Empire, others viewed him as aloof and cruel. His retreat to Capri, where he indulged in hedonistic pursuits away from Rome, added to his negative image.

What was Tiberius’ relationship with the Senate and the people of Rome?

Tiberius had a strained relationship with the Senate, often viewing them with suspicion and purging those he perceived as threats. His policies, such as increasing taxation and his authoritarian style, alienated many Romans. However, his earlier years as emperor saw attempts to maintain a facade of cooperation with the Senate.

What was Tiberius’ legacy?

Tiberius’ legacy is complex and debated among historians. While he maintained the stability of the Empire during his reign, his methods often involved repression and brutality. His rule is often contrasted with the more celebrated reign of Augustus. Nonetheless, Tiberius’ policies and actions shaped the Roman Empire during a crucial period of transition.
